qas.question: What type of construction is best for applications that need to portion space carefully?
What gets mounted in the middle of two parallel planes in a cordwood construction?
What do insulating cards prevent between interconnection layers?
What type of component has to be used in cordwood construction to its detriment?
What force caused the physical damage to components that affected the Apollo program?
What does not save significant space?

plausible_answers.text: special nickel-leaded components had to be used to allow the interconnecting welds to be made

qas.question: What was one advantage of this system?
Components located on the exterior are what?

context: <a0_0><b5_0>Cordwood<a0_0/> construction<b5_0/> can save significant space and was often used with wire-ended components in applications where space was at a premium (such as missile guidance and telemetry systems) and in high-speed computers, where short traces were important. In cordwood construction, <a1_0>axial-leaded components<a1_0/> were mounted between two parallel planes. <b6_0>The components<b6_0/> were either soldered together with jumper wire, or they were connected to other components by thin nickel ribbon welded at right angles onto the component leads. To avoid <a2_0>shorting<a2_0/> together different interconnection layers, thin insulating cards were placed between them. Perforations or holes in the cards allowed component leads to project through to the next interconnection layer. One disadvantage of this system was that <b7_0>special <a3_0>nickel-leaded<a3_0/> components had to be used to allow the interconnecting welds to be made<b7_0/>. <a4_0>Differential thermal expansion<a4_0/> of the component could put pressure on the leads of the components and the PCB traces and cause physical damage (as was seen in several modules on the Apollo program). Additionally, components located in the interior are <b8_0>difficult to replace<b8_0/>. Some versions of cordwood construction used soldered single-sided PCBs as the interconnection method (as pictured), allowing the use of normal-leaded components.
